prompts.name: Generate Commit Message (Conventional Commits)
prompts.description: Generate git commit message following Conventional Commits specification
prompts.content:
Write a git commit message following the Conventional Commit specification. The message must be in English and respect the following structure:

Begin with a type from the list: feat, fix, docs, chore, refactor, ci, build, style, perf, or test.
Optionally include a scope in parentheses, such as api, db, or ui, etc.
After the type and optional scope, add a colon, a space, and a concise subject.
The subject should be a short description of the changes made, no longer than 50 characters.
If the commit includes a breaking change, add an exclamation mark before the colon, like this: feat(api)!:.
Following the subject, leave a blank line.
Use bullet points (-) to summarize what has been changed, with each line being a maximum of 100 characters.
The message should focus on key points and avoid unnecessary details.

Example message:
fix(api): resolve CORS issue in production env

- corrected CORS policy to accept custom headers
- updated middleware to handle preflight requests
- removed unused CORS library, which caused conflicts

Ensure the message is no more than 100 characters per line and follow the structure provided.

prompts.name: Write Java Documentation
prompts.content:
Generate comprehensive JavaDoc documentation for this code including:
- Purpose and functionality
- @param tags for all parameters
- @return tag for return values
- @throws tags for exceptions
- Usage examples in @code blocks
- Edge cases and error handling notes
- Dependencies and requirements

prompts.name: Generate Java Unit Tests
prompts.description: Create JUnit unit tests for Java code
prompts.content:
Generate comprehensive JUnit unit tests for this Java code:
- Test happy path scenarios
- Test edge cases and boundary conditions
- Test error handling and exceptions
- Use JUnit 5 and appropriate assertions
- Include @BeforeEach setup if needed
- Use meaningful test method names
- Aim for high code coverage
